Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
For myself, the key distinction is that statistics have a belief that the statistical model is an accurate reflection or description of the world. Machine learners do not hold such a belief - a mathematical model does not have to be an accurate description. So when a statistician applies a linear regression model to housing prices, very often he is stating a belief that housing prices change linearly with the size of the house. That belief is then tested by calculating p-values and confidence rates, which confirms or rejects the model as an accurate representation of the world. This is also what Physicists are doing when they are conducting experiments with the Large Hadron Collider. They hold the belief that the Standard Model of Quantum Mechanics accurately describes our world and that data collected from the LHC allows us to test for the existence of the Higgs Boson with very high rates of confidence. Machine Learners on the other hand do not care if the mathematical model we are using is an accurate representation of the task or world as long as we get good results in the form of prediction accuracy on new data. This is the perspective of an engineer and not a scientist - we just care that it works and that we can get it to do what we want.
